awd_titl_txt: Knowledge of the Nonempirical Environment in the Bering Strait

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This project involved a collaboration between the Alaska Native non-profit Tribal consortium Kawerak, Inc. and 18 federally recognized Tribes to document stories, knowledge and experiences related to the supernatural world. The collaborating Tribes included Shishmaref, Diomede, Savoonga, Brevig Mission, Teller, Mary's Igloo, King Island, Nome Eskimo Community, Solomon, Council, White Mountain, Golovin, Elim, Shaktoolik, Unalakleet, Stebbins and St. Michael. Over two hundred region residents participated in the project, which will produce a volume of stories. The project also included extensive archival research (in the Ernest Burch Jr. Collection at the University of Alaska Fairbanks, the Eskimo Heritage Program archive at Kawerak, and the ANCSA Collection held by the Bureau of Indian Affairs) and the creation of a guide to archival materials.  The supernatural world includes phenomena such as non-ordinary creatures, non-human persons, uncommon sounds and lights, and related experiences. These phenomena are culturally specific to the Indigenous cultures and communities of the Bering Strait region. The knowledge, beliefs, and experiences shared by region residents on this topic are personally and culturally meaningful, and often spiritually important, and are situated within the traditions, values, and cultures of region communities. These stories and experiences remain important parts of community life and tradition for many people in the Kawerak region.


Last Modified: 04/02/2024
Modified by: Julie M Raymond-Yakoubian
